item.title: About
item.description:
Hi, Iâ€™m Shaunak Datar â€” an electronics engineering student at VJTI, Mumbai, obsessed with systems that live close to the metal.

Most of my time goes into building custom development boards, writing bare-metal drivers, and working on my own operating system for the Raspberry Pi. I enjoy reverse engineering datasheets, bringing up hardware from scratch, and poking at memory-mapped registers until something cool happens.

Currently, Iâ€™m contributing to RTEMS as a Google Summer of Code 2025 student, adding support for peripherals like PWM, I2C, and DMA on the Raspberry Pi 4. I also like exploring compilers, messing with LLVM, and learning Rust when Iâ€™m not knee-deep in embedded code.

item.title: Running RTEMS on Raspberry Pi 4B
item.description:
RTEMS (Real-Time Executive for Multiprocessor Systems) is a real-time operating system used in embedded systems, offering a rich set of Board Support Packages (BSPs) for various platforms. One such platform is the Raspberry Pi 4B, a popular board among hobbyists, educators, and industry professionals. In this post, Iâ€™ll walk you through setting up RTEMS on the Raspberry Pi 4B from scratch.

Letâ€™s dive in!

ðŸš€ Setting Up the Environment

First, create a working directory. Ensure that git is installed on your host machine.
